Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content:
Does anyone know when the kmd team is going to finish crediting wallets that were swept as a result of the potential hack?

 I‚Äôve been a Komodo supporter since the beginning and luckily had moved 95% of my kmd out of Agama before the sweep.  

However, I‚Äôm still very disappointed that this happened and it‚Äôs made me lose confidence almost entirely in the project.  The fact that their was a vulnerability and kmd team was able to gain access and sweep my kmd even though everything was offline.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
the hacker stole the passphrases, we took it from him
over 90% of the funds have been returned, alternative was to just let the hacker take it permanently
if your refund is not processed yet, let me know the address and i will look into it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
if it werent for the hacker stealing the passphrases, we wouldnt have any access. unfortunately, hacks happen across this space on a regular basis and we were specifically targeted with a long term attack. At least we will make everyone 100% refunded. how many other projects have done that?
also, the blockchain was not hacked. it was an upstream library (npm) for one of the half dozen wallets that was. we are definitely tightening our security review process and this was a big wakeup call. not just for us, but all wallet providers that use node.js

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: Indeed

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: @jl777c I understand the blockchain itself wasn‚Äôt hacked but Agama was supposed to be the safe wallet for kmd storage.   It would be like someone being able to steal private keys from an electrum wallet and then sweeping the bitcoins out of them.  Appreciate the team‚Äôs honesty and transparency.  I‚Äôll be in touch w info about my kmd address.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: @OriginalBitcoin https://blog.npmjs.org/post/185397814280/plot-to-steal-cryptocurrency-foiled-by-the-npm

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: @OriginalBitcoin  Electrum was hacked not too long ago as well. It's something that could have happen to any team and it was dealt with the best way possible.

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: Does it make you question where you leave large amounts of funds? It should. Users need to start using cold storage wallets as opposed to hot storage for these same reasons. It's a cold shower for investors and developers alike.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: firefox had a zero day vuln targeting crypto

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dozens of other crypto related hacks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and the new trend is to attack the development pipeline

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: More attacks will come

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is a universal attack, not just KMD specific

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: hardware wallets or nodes that are airgapped seems to be the best way

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but even hardware wallets if the hacker gets access to it, the privkey can be extracted

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i am not saying this makes the agama incident ok

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: @PTYX  are you referring to the recent Electrum botnet at the end of April?  If so that was different because it was user error and users were tricked into downloading an infected version of electrum

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: https://thehackernews.com/2019/04/electrum-bitcoin-wallet-botnet.html?m=1

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the more moving parts, the more attack surface

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: cli wallet has much less attack surfact

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a GUI adds a lot more surface, even if all it does is access the cli

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: usually it is the big projects that are targeted

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: @PTYX unfortunately true

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: @jl777c yeah cli are less prone to attacks but in order to get kmd mainstream, a GUI is a must.  It has also bothered me since day one that you don‚Äôt need to enter a password to send kmd from agama.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well, i added the ability for KMD to have a walletpassphrase end of last year

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess that feature is not in the GUI yet

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: Yea in the GUI

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: pretty sure oceanQT supports walletpassphrase

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: Ok thanks. Always just stuck w Agama.

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: But I‚Äôll look into oceanQT

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think oceanQT has much less attack surface than node.js and it should be a familiar interface with walletpassphrase

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: So for my own learning, how is it possible for a hacker to sweep my kmd coins when the wallet itself is physically offline.  Why is the paraphrase to the wallet stored online?

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: @jl777c I always thought that wallet seed is not broadcasted?

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: It‚Äôs not, that was the hackers malware he snuck in to the dependency

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: So there was malware inserted into Agama?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: https://blog.npmjs.org/post/185397814280/plot-to-steal-cryptocurrency-foiled-by-the-npm

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: I‚Äôm still confused because I wasn‚Äôt using v0.3.5

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: Pretty sure I was logging in w an earlier version.  Maybe 0.3.1?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: @OriginalBitcoin did you check your address in an explorer?

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: Yes that‚Äôs how I knew kmd team had swept the coins

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Unlikely, SPV servers wouldn‚Äôt have connected

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @OriginalBitcoin if you ever used the agama 3.5, even once, that could have been enough

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: The version I was using had a d or b at the end of the number but maybe I did use 3.5 once one another computer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, unfortunately that is all it takes

Author: OriginalBitcoin#4548
Content: Thanks for your help everyone! @jl777c will message you the address tomorrow.  Off to bed! Nighttime here

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: @jl777c is right here. For those who are not necessarily a developer, you still have to know that the code review of blockchains projects are certainly the most difficult ones that exist. There is a lot of money in this industry, so a lot of people want to take advantage of it. The projects that will have the most rigor or those who will manage this kind of attack will emerge in this industry. In my personal opinion because of the javascript package manager, do not use this language, too risky.

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: Well, this is not the first time that the JavaScript ecosystem is really dangerous, I say banning a specific programming language in a specific industry.

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: As a reminder: https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.theregister.co.uk/AMP/2018/07/12/npm_eslint/

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: Well, yes. But most of people that use JavaScript use npm or yarn. But you right.

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: Unfortunately most of people in this industry do not have your rigor. What you described should be mandatory but unfortunately this is not the case.

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: I hope so.
